Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my sister’s laughter echoing as our family tossed around ideas for the weekend. My mother looked at me, her eyes hopeful. “You’ll come with us this time, right?” she asked. I nodded, feeling the warmth of belonging, the comfort of being a brother who shows up. But my phone buzzed—a reminder from the pharmacy. Tomorrow, I was scheduled to fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription. The margin for error was razor-thin; one slip could mean disaster for a patient who trusted me with their life. My family’s voices faded into the background as I pictured the vials, the calculations, the double-checking. I wanted to be present, to laugh and plan with them, but the weight of my responsibility as a pharmacist pressed down on me. My heart tugged in two directions, each role demanding my full attention, each expectation impossible to ignore. I stared at my hands, torn between the safety of a patient and the happiness of my family, unsure which part of me should take the lead.
